Requirements: To complete an application, prospective students must submit either the Common Application or the Coalition Application, which includes the Stony Brook Supplement questions and a personal essay. A $50 non-refundable application fee and official high school transcript(s) are also required. Stony Brook University is test-optional; submission of SAT or ACT scores is not required. While not required for admission, applicants may submit up to two letters of recommendation.

Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies

Requirements: To apply for undergraduate admission, applicants must submit a completed Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir. A $50 non-refundable application fee or an approved fee waiver is required. Necessary documents include official high school transcript(s) and one letter of recommendation from a school counselor or teacher. If applicable, official college transcripts for any completed coursework must also be submitted. An essay is required as part of the application.

Qualified first-year and transfer students who have indicated their interest in the major on their applications may be admitted directly to the major at the time of their admission to the University. Students who did not apply for the major and are not admitted to the major when they enter the University may apply for admission to the major provided that their cumulative g.p.a. is at least 2.80 and that they have received a grade of B- or higher in MAT 125 or MAT 131 or MAT 141 or AMS 151 and a grade of B- or higher in MAT 126 or MAT 132 or MAT 142 or AMS 161.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics & Statistics

Requirements: Application requirements for first-year students include the submission of a Common Application or ApplySUNY application, a non-refundable application fee, official high school transcripts, one required teacher or counselor recommendation, and a personal essay. Stony Brook University is test-optional and does not require SAT or ACT scores for students applying for admission for terms through spring 2025.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Art History & Criticism

Requirements: Admission is contingent on a successful portfolio review by the Art Department. The portfolio review takes place only after the student has been admitted to the University. For portfolio submission guidelines, please visit stonybrook.edu/art.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Art, Studio
Bachelor of Arts in Asian & Asian American Studies

Requirements: Stony Brook University takes a holistic approach to reviewing applications. We seek to enroll students with diverse backgrounds, interests, and abilities who will take advantage of our outstanding academic and extracurricular offerings. Each application is reviewed on an individual basis. There are no score cutoffs for admission. We look for a strong high school academic program, and we consider your highest scores on the SAT or ACT. We also consider factors such as your extracurricular activities, special talents or abilities, and your personal essay. Students who have challenged themselves with an Advanced Placement (AP) or honors curriculum will be given special consideration.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Astronomy/Planetary Sciences

Requirements: Stony Brook will holistically review your application and take all parts of your application into consideration, including: your high school transcript, the rigor and strength of your academic program, your supplemental essay and letters of recommendation, and standardized test scores (if you choose to submit them). For this major, students should complete at least one semester of calculus and at least one semester of either chemistry or physics before entering the major.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences

Requirements: A completed application for first-year admission includes: The Common Application or Coalition Application, a $50 non-refundable application fee, your official high school transcript, one teacher or counselor recommendation, and the Stony Brook Writing Supplement. Stony Brook is test-optional and will not require SAT or ACT scores for most applicants.

To apply as a first-year student, you must submit either the Common Application or the SUNY Application, along with a $50 non-refundable application fee. Required documents include your official high school transcript(s), one letter of recommendation from a school counselor or teacher, and an application essay. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application.

To be eligible to declare the Biology major, students must complete CHE 131 General Chemistry I and one of the following courses with a grade of C or higher: BIO 201, BIO 202 or BIO 203. A grade of C or higher is also required in CHE 132 General Chemistry II.

Applicants must submit either the Common Application or the Coalition Application, an application essay, an official high school transcript, and one teacher/counselor recommendation. A nonrefundable $50 application fee or fee waiver is also required. Submission of official SAT or ACT scores is optional.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Biomedical Engineering

Requirements: Qualified freshmen and transfers who have indicated their interest in the major on their applications may be admitted directly to the major. Admission is highly competitive and based on a review of the student’s application materials. Students not admitted directly to the major may apply for admission after their first year at Stony Brook provided they meet the secondary admission requirements. To be considered for admission after the first year, students must have a 3.2 cumulative grade point average and must have completed at least two of the following courses with a grade of B or better: BUS 115, ECO 108, AMS 102, and MAT 123 (or a higher-level calculus course).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Business Management

Requirements: To apply as a freshman, you will need to submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; Official high school transcript(s); One teacher or counselor recommendation; One essay; Application fee. Stony Brook University is test-optional, which means you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application for admission.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Chemical & Molecular Engineering

Requirements:
To be considered for admission, the following must be on file in the Office of Undergraduate Admissions by the appropriate deadline:
- Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir
- $50 non-refundable application fee or fee waiver
- Official high school transcript(s)
- Official SAT or ACT Scores (Optional)
- One teacher/counselor recommendation
- Essay

To be considered for admission, you should have a strong college preparatory curriculum including: 4 units of English, 4 units of social studies, 3 units of mathematics (4 units are recommended), 3 units of science (4 units are recommended), and 2 or 3 units of a foreign language.

Students who have completed the prerequisites with grades of C or higher and have a GPA of 3.2 in all mathematics, physics, and chemistry courses applicable to the major requirements and an overall GPA of 3.0 may be admitted to the Civil Engineering major.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Civil Engineering

Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, please submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; Official High School Transcript(s); One Teacher/Counselor Recommendation; Standardized Test Scores (SAT/ACT); Application Fee or Fee Waiver. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning you have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores with your application.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Climate Science

Requirements: Completed applications are reviewed by the CLS Admissions Committee. The following documents must be submitted to the Office of Student Services by the February 1st deadline: 1. A completed Stony Brook University Health Professions (SHP) application. This application is available on the School of Health Professions Office of Student Services website. 2. Application fee of $100.00. 3. Two letters of recommendation from college professors or other professionals who are familiar with the applicant’s academic ability and/or work performance. 4. Official transcripts from ALL colleges and universities attended. 5. A personal statement indicating why you are choosing the CLS profession. 6. International applicants who have completed their post-secondary education in a non-English speaking country must take the TOEFL or IELTS exam.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Sciences

Requirements: Prospective students must apply using either the Common Application or the Coalition Application. Required application materials include an official high school transcript, a letter of recommendation from a school counselor, a teacher evaluation/recommendation, and a personal essay. Stony Brook is test-optional, meaning SAT or ACT scores are not required for admission.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Coastal Environmental Studies

Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must submit either the Common Application or SUNY Application, an application fee or fee waiver, official high school transcript(s), and one letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor. Submission of SAT/ACT scores is optional.

All first-year students must submit the following: Common Application or Coalition Application, powered by Scoir; $50 non-refundable application fee; Official high school transcript; One letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor; Essay; SAT or ACT Scores (Test-Optional).
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Computer Engineering

Requirements: First-year applicants must submit a Common Application or Coalition Application, a $50 non-refundable application fee, an official high school transcript, and one teacher/counselor recommendation (up to three will be reviewed). For applicants to majors in the College of Engineering and Applied Sciences, such as Computer Science, calculus is required. Stony Brook is test-optional for the Spring 2024 and Fall 2024 application cycles, meaning students can choose whether or to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of their application.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

Requirements: Admission to the Creative Writing and Literature major is competitive and is by application only. Application materials may be obtained in the Creative Writing Program Office, 2042 Humanities. To be considered for admission into the major, students must have: 1. A grade of B or higher in CWL 202 Introduction to Creative Writing. 2. A sample of the student's creative work (no more than ten pages of prose or poetry). 3. A short application form (available from the Creative Writing Program Office).
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Creative Writing

Requirements: First-year applicants must apply using either the Common Application or the Coalition Application. Required documents include an official high school transcript, an application essay, and one letter of recommendation from a teacher or counselor. A non-refundable $50 application fee is also required.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Data Science

Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you will need to submit either the Common Application or the Coalition Application, an application fee (or waiver), official high school transcripts, one teacher letter of recommendation, and a school counselor letter of recommendation. Submission of SAT or ACT scores is optional for most applicants.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Earth & Space Sciences

Requirements: The minor in Accounting is open to all students who meet the prerequisites. The minor in Accounting is awarded to students who complete 24 credits of required courses with a grade of C or higher in each course. Students should declare the minor in Accounting by the beginning of their junior year to ensure that they can complete all requirements on time. Students must have a cumulative g.p.a. of 3.2, with an average g.p.a. of 3.0 in the following four courses: BUS 115, BUS 210, BUS 215, and BUS 220. Meeting these requirements does not guarantee admission into the accounting minor. Admission is competitive and based on the student’s g.p.a. in the prerequisite courses.

The minor in Africana Studies requires 18 credits.

1. AFS 101 or AFS 102
2. One course from the AFS 200-level offerings
3. Four additional courses from the AFS 300- or 400-level offerings. Up to two of these courses may be satisfied by cross-listed courses offered in other departments, or by appropriate study-abroad courses, with the permission of the undergraduate program director.
4. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

1. Two introductory courses chosen from the following: ANP 101, ANP 120, ANP 201, ANP 202.
2. One area course chosen from the following: ANP 250, ANP 260, ANP 270.
3. One methods course chosen from the following: ANP 307, ANP 326, ANP 350.
4. Three additional ANP courses at the 300 level.
5. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Declaration of the Minor

Students should declare the minor in anthropology by the beginning of their junior year at the latest. To declare, students should contact the undergraduate program director in the Department of Anthropology.
To be admitted to the minor, students must have a g.p.a. of 3.00 in all mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics courses.
Program name: Minor in Applied Mathematics and Statistics

Requirements: The minor in Studio Art is open to all undergraduate students. Students must complete an application which is reviewed by the department faculty for admission to the minor. A portfolio is not required for application to the minor, but students may be asked to submit a portfolio for placement in advanced courses.

The minor in Asian American Studies requires 18 credits.

Completion of the minor requires a C or higher in all courses applied to the minor.

1. AAS 201 Introduction to Asian American Studies
2. AAS 326 Asian American Psychology
3. Four additional courses from the list of approved courses, at least three of which must be at the 300 level or higher.
Students should meet with the undergraduate program director to have their major/minor course program approved.
Program name: Minor in Asian and Asian American Studies

Requirements:
Declaration of the minor should be initiated in the Asian and Asian American Studies Department. The minor requires 18 credits. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A maximum of one course in the minor may be taken under the Pass/NC option. Completion of the minor requires 18 credits.

Required Course (3 credits)
Choose one of the following:
*   AAS 216: Introduction to Buddhism
*   AAS 217: Introduction to Daoism

Electives (15 credits)
Choose five courses from the following, with at least one from Group A and one from Group B.

Group A: Traditions and Texts
*   AAS 216: Introduction to Buddhism
*   AAS 217: Introduction to Daoism
*   AAS 370: Chinese Philosophy
*   AAS 380: Islam in Asia
*   AAS 381: Hinduism
*   AAS 382: Religions of Japan
*   AAS 383: Religions of China
*   AAS 385: Philosophies of India
*   AAS 401: Historical and Social Theory in Asian and Asian American Studies

Group B: Modernity, Politics, and Society
*   AAS 201: Introduction to Asian American Studies
*   AAS 220: Chinese Civilization
*   AAS 230: Indian Civilization
*   AAS 250: Japanese Civilization
*   AAS 260: Korean Civilization
*   AAS 300: Topics in Asian and Asian American Studies
*   AAS 326: Modern Korea
*   AAS 354: Contemporary Japan
*   AAS 355: Postwar Japan
*   AAS 379: Law and Society in Pre-Modern China

Completion of the minor requires 20 credits.

1. Two introductory courses: AST 101/AST 112 and AST 203.
2. One upper-division course: AST 301.
3. Two additional upper-division courses: AST 346, AST 347, AST 403, or AST 443.
4. One AST laboratory course: AST 248 or PHY 251/PHY 252.
5. All courses for the minor must be passed with a grade of C or higher.
6. At least 11 of the 20 credits for the minor must be taken at Stony Brook.
7. No courses taken under the Pass/NC option may be applied to the minor.

Declaration of the Minor
To declare the minor, students should fill out the Minor Declaration Form and bring it to the undergraduate program director in the Department of Physics and Astronomy for a signature. At this time, the specific courses that will satisfy the minor requirements must be approved by the director. Students should consult with the director before registration to ensure that their plan of study is appropriate.

Students interested in the minor should meet with the undergraduate program director to discuss the curriculum and to obtain an application. A minimum GPA of 3.0 in all courses is required for admission to the minor. Completion of the minor requires a minimum of 21 credits. All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade. A grade of C or higher is required in all courses for the minor.

Students should declare the minor in Biology by the beginning of their junior year, but no later than the first week of their last semester. To be eligible to declare the minor, students must have completed at least one biology course at Stony Brook with a grade of C or higher.
Students should declare the minor in Black Heritage Studies by the time they have junior standing. The minor declaration form is available here.

The minor in China Studies requires 21 credits.

A. Language Requirement (6 credits minimum)

*   CHI 211 Second Year Chinese I
*   CHI 212 Second Year Chinese II
*   or demonstration of equivalent proficiency

B. Two Courses from the following (6 credits)

*   CHI 311 Third Year Chinese I
*   CHI 312 Third Year Chinese II
*   CHI 411 Advanced Chinese I
*   CHI 412 Advanced Chinese II

C. Three Courses from the following (9 credits)

*   ASN 221 Chinese Literature in Translation
*   ASN 222 Traditional Chinese Culture
*   ASN 223 Modern Chinese Culture
*   ASN 321 Studies in Traditional Chinese Literature
*   ASN 322 Studies in Modern Chinese Literature
*   CHI 331 Introduction to Classical Chinese I
*   CHI 332 Introduction to Classical Chinese II
*   HIS 219 The History of the People's Republic of China
*   HIS 226 Traditional China
*   HIS 227 Modern China
*   PHL 305 Chinese Philosophy

D. All courses for the minor must be passed with a grade of C or higher.

E. No more than three credits of courses taken under the Pass/NC option may be applied to the minor.

Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least nine credits applied to the minor must be in courses numbered 300 or higher.

Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 21 credits must be from courses in the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (ATM, MAR, CSO). Students should declare the minor in Climate Solutions no later than the first semester of their junior year. Before declaring the minor, students should meet with the undergraduate program director.

Students should declare the minor in Coastal Environmental Studies by the beginning of their junior year to ensure that they can complete all requirements. Declaration forms are available at the Undergraduate Program Director’s office, 105 Endeavour Hall (632-8674).

To declare the minor, students must have a cumulative grade point average of 2.5. The minor in Communication requires 18 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Requirements are as follows: COM 100 Introduction to Communication, COM 205 Interpersonal Communication, COM 207 Communication Theory. Nine additional credits in COM at the 300 or 400 level.
Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Students must have a G.P.A. of 3.0 or better to be accepted into the minor.

Completion of the minor requires a minimum of 22 credits. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Students must have a g.p.a. of 3.2 in the courses CSE 114, 214, 215 to be admitted to the minor. For an automatic approval of the minor declaration, students must have a GPA of 3.2 or higher in CSE 114, CSE 214 and CSE 215, and have a C or higher in each of these courses. All other students are admitted on a space-available basis.

Students wishing to declare a minor in Creative Writing must have a cumulative grade point average of at least 3.00 and have completed CWL 202 with a grade of B or higher. Students should fill out the Minor Declaration Form available in the Creative Writing and Literature office, Humanities 2089, by appointment. The form should be submitted to the undergraduate program director.

Students should declare the minor in Digital Arts by the end of the first semester of their junior year. To declare the minor, students should fill out a Declaration of Major/Minor Form and submit to the Director of the Digital Arts Minor.

Students should declare the minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact (EHI) no later than the first semester of the junior year. Declaration forms may be obtained from the SoMAS Undergraduate Director's Office. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. No more than one course (or 4 credits) may be taken under the Pass/NC option. At least nine credits of the minor must be from courses offered by SoMAS (ATM, ENS, MAR, MTD, etc.).
Program name: Minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact

Requirements: All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires a minimum of 22 credits. 1. Required Courses: ESE 124, ESE 211, ESE 224, ESE 271. 2. Electives: At least two courses from the following: ESE 272, ESE 273, ESE 280, ESE 300, ESE 301, ESE 304, ESE 305, ESE 306, ESE 311, ESE 314, ESE 315, ESE 323, ESE 324, ESE 330, ESE 337, ESE 340, ESE 341, ESE 343, ESE 344, ESE 345, ESE 347, ESE 350, ESE 352, ESE 355, ESE 356, ESE 358, ESE 360, ESE 363, ESE 366, ESE 372, ESE 380, ESE 381, ESE 382.

The minor in English consists of 21 credits (seven 3-credit courses). All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A maximum of one course may be transferred. The requirements are as follows: 1. EGL 204. 2. One course in British literature before 1800. 3. One course in American literature before 1900. 4. Four additional EGL courses at the 200, 300, or 400 level.

Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. A grade of C or higher is required in all courses applied to the minor. Students should declare the minor by the time they are in their junior year. For more information, students should contact the undergraduate program director or the faculty director.
Program name: Minor in Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning

Requirements:
All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

Required Courses (9 credits):

ESG 100 Introduction to Engineering Science
ESG 201 Engineering and Technology in Society
CIV 210 Surveying
One of the following (3 credits):

GEO 102 The Earth
GEO 103 The Earth through Time
Three of the following (9 credits):

CIV 330 Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment Design
CIV 331 Hydrologic and Hydraulic Design
CIV 333 Coastal Engineering
ESG 302 Thermodynamics of Materials
MEC 260 Engineering Statics
To be eligible to declare the minor, students must have completed at least one course that can be used to fulfill the requirements for the minor with a grade of C or higher.

The minor in Ethnomusicology requires a minimum of 21 credits. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A minimum of 12 credits must be from upper-division courses (300-level or higher). A maximum of three credits of MUS 487 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the minor. Required Courses (9 credits): MUS 119 Introduction to World Music Cultures, MUS 250 Theory and Practice of Ethnomusicology, MUS 350 Ethnography of Music, MUS 450 Advanced Studies in Ethnomusicology. Electives (12 credits): Students must complete an additional four courses (12 credits) selected from the following list: MUS 318, MUS 325, MUS 326, MUS 327, MUS 328, MUS 329, MUS 487, AFS 375, AAS 380, LLL 320.

To declare the minor, students must meet with one of the Film and Screen Studies co-directors to discuss their interests and plan a program of study. The minor must be declared before the student has completed 12 credits of coursework applicable to the minor.
Program name: Minor in Film and Screen Studies

Requirements: The Minor in Filmmaking is open to all undergraduate students. Students must declare the Minor in Filmmaking no later than the first semester of their junior year. Interested students should meet with the Minor Director to plan a course of study. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

Completion of ECO 108 with a grade of C or higher. Completion of AMS 102 or AMS 110 or MAT 125 or MAT 131 or MAT 141 with a grade of C or higher. A minimum g.p.a. of 3.2 is required to declare the minor.

Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in French beyond FRN 212. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Up to six credits from a Study Abroad program may be applied to the minor with approval of the undergraduate program director.

The minor in Geology is open to all students. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. 1. Two of the following courses with labs: * GEO 102/112 The Earth * GEO 103 The Earth through Time * GEO 122 Physical Geology. 2. Four upper-division GEO courses, at least three of which must be at the 300 level or higher. GEO 310, Introduction to Geophysics, is recommended. The department chairperson may substitute courses from other departments where appropriate. At least 12 credits of the minor must be taken at Stony Brook.
The minor in Geospatial Science is open to all undergraduate students at Stony Brook. Students who are interested in the minor should contact Professor E. Troy Rasbury.

Students should declare the minor as early as possible and no later than the first semester of their senior year. Declaration forms may be obtained from the Globalization Studies and International Relations office, and are also available at http://www.stonybrook.edu/global.
Program name: Minor in Globalization Studies and International Relations

Requirements: To declare the minor, students must complete the Undergraduate Minor Declaration Form, which is available on the Registrar's website.
Program name: Minor in Health, Medicine, and Society

Requirements: Declaration of the minor is open to all students in good academic standing. The minor requires the completion of 24 credits, including the four-course language sequence in Modern Greek (HLL 101, HLL 102, HLL 201, and HLL 202) and two courses (six credits) from the list of electives below. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Students should declare the minor in History as early as possible and no later than the first semester of their junior year. Forms for this purpose are available from the Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Department of History.

Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 18 credits must be in courses at the 300 level or higher. Required Course: HIS 290: Topics in the History of Health, Science, and the Environment. Electives: 15 credits selected from the following list, at least 9 of which must be at the 300-level or higher. No more than one course from outside the History Department will be counted toward the minor. Other courses may be accepted by petition to the undergraduate director. List of courses: AFS 368/WST 368, AMS 318, BCP 405, BIO 358, ENV 301, HIS 214, HIS 244, HIS 317, HIS 343, HIS 368, HIS 379/SOC 379, HIS 392, HIS 398, PHI 383, POL 310, SOC 340, SOC 344, WST 392.
Program name: Minor in History of Health, Science, and the Environment

Requirements: Declaration of the minor requires a cumulative grade point average of 3.00.

All courses required for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and passed with a grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.

Required Courses:
ISE 108 Fundamentals of IT or CSE 101 Computer Science Principles
ISE 208 Object Oriented Programming in Java
ISE 218 Fundamentals of Network & Data Communications
ISE 305 Database Design and Practice
ISE 316 Software Engineering
ISE 321 Introduction to Information Systems Security
One upper-division elective course from the following list: ISE 300, ISE 304, ISE 306, ISE 311, ISE 312, ISE 320, ISE 323, ISE 325, ISE 331, ISE 332, ISE 364.

The minor in Italian American Studies requires 18 credits, of which at least nine must be in upper-division courses. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires a g.p.a. of 2.00 in all courses applied to the minor.

The minor in Japanese Studies requires 18 credits. A maximum of six credits may be transferred from another institution. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 of the 18 credits must be in courses numbered 300 or higher.

A. Language Requirement (6 credits)
Choose one of the following sequences:
* JPN 201 Intermediate Japanese I and JPN 202 Intermediate Japanese II
* JPN 311 Advanced Japanese I and JPN 312 Advanced Japanese II

B. Culture and Literature Requirement (9 credits)
Choose three courses from the following list. At least two of the three must be taken at Stony Brook.
* AAS 370/JPN 370 Is Japan a Post-colonial Empire?
* EGL 336/JPN 336 Asian American Film and Video
* JPN 112 Modern Japan
* JPN 215 Introduction to Japanese Culture and People
* JPN 305 Japanese Popular Culture
* JPN 330 Topics in Japanese Studies
* JPN 334 Survey of Japanese Literature
* JPN 335 Japanese Film
* JPN 410 Readings in Japanese Studies
* Relevant topics courses in AAS, ARH, CCS, EGL, HIS, PHI, SOC, THR may be accepted with the approval of the undergraduate director.

C. Upper-Division Writing Requirement
Students should consult with the department advisor to ensure that their plan for completing the Upper Division Writing Requirement is consistent with university graduation requirements for the minor. Students who are preparing to write a senior thesis or research paper are encouraged to take the JPN 410 or another 400-level course that requires a substantial research paper.

D. Grade Requirement
All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

The Minor in Jazz Music provides a course of study for students who wish to pursue jazz studies to supplement their major. Declaration of the minor is available to students who have completed one semester of MUS 201 (Jazz Improvisation I) with a grade of C or better. All students wishing to enroll in Jazz Combos and/or Jazz Big Band must first perform a successful audition for the Director of Jazz Studies. Completion of the minor requires 19-20 credits.
The minor in journalism is open to all students in good standing at Stony Brook. Declaration of the minor is made through the student's major department.
Students should declare the minor in Judaic Studies by the beginning of the junior year. To plan a course of study, students should consult the undergraduate program director.

The minor in Korean Studies is open to all undergraduate students. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits, of which at least 12 credits must be in courses at the 300 level or higher. No more than three credits of KOR 447 may be used to satisfy the requirements of the minor. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Program name: Minor in Latin American and Caribbean Studies

Requirements: Students should declare the minor in Linguistics no later than the middle of their junior year by completing the minor declaration form and submitting it to the Linguistics Undergraduate Director.

To be admitted to the minor, students must have a GPA of 3.00. The minor requires completion of a minimum of 18 credits. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Required courses include MEC 310, MEC 410, MEC 411, and three electives (9 credits) chosen from an approved list.

To declare a minor in Marine Sciences, students should go to the SoMAS undergraduate office in 145 Endeavour Hall. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 18 credits. 1. MAR 101 or MAR 104; 2. 15 additional credits in MAR and ATM courses, including at least two courses at the 300 level or higher. No more than three credits of MAR 487 may be used to satisfy the requirements for the minor. The one-credit MAR 250 does not count toward the 18 total credits for the MAR minor. For Marine Science majors, only six credits of coursework may be double counted toward the MAR major and minor.

The minor in mass communication, offered by the School of Journalism, consists of 18 credits. A grade of C or higher in each course is required. Students must apply to the minor. Acceptance is competitive and is based on a student’s overall academic record. All students must complete an online application.

Declaration of the minor is open to all students at Stony Brook. Declaration of the minor is made in the Materials Science and Engineering office after successful completion of the prerequisite courses with grades of C or higher.
Students should declare the minor in Mathematics before the start of their final semester. Application forms for the minor are available at the Mathematics Undergraduate Office.

The minor in Mechanical Engineering is open to all University students in good standing. Students should declare their intention to complete the minor as early as possible. To be granted the minor, students must complete the following requirements with a grade of C or higher in each course.
To declare a minor in Middle Eastern Studies, a student must have a G.P.A. of 2.0 or better and submit a Minor Declaration Form to the MES Undergraduate Director and the Registrar's Office.

Admission to the minor in Music is by audition with the Department of Music. Interested students should see the Undergraduate Director in the Music Department for further information and to declare the minor. Completion of the minor requires 22-25 credits. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. No more than one course may be taken under the Pass/NC option. Transfer credits are not accepted toward the Music minor.

To declare the Music and Technology Minor, a student must have completed MUS 119 with a B or better. Students should fill out the Minor Declaration form available at the Music Department office. Declaration must be completed before the beginning of the student's final semester. The minor requires a total of 23-24 credits. At least 12 credits must be in upper-division MUS courses. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

To be admitted to the music minor programs, students must consult with the undergraduate director and receive his/her approval. The minor in music theory is awarded for successful completion of 18 credits distributed as follows: Required courses (12 credits): MUS 131 Harmony and Counterpoint I, MUS 132 Harmony and Counterpoint II, MUS 231 Harmony and Counterpoint III, MUS 232 Harmony and Counterpoint IV. Two upper-division courses in music theory (6 credits).

Application for admission to the minor can be made once a student has achieved U3 status at Stony Brook and has a minimum GPA of 3.0. Application must be made before completion of the first semester of the senior year.
To declare the minor, students should contact the undergraduate program director listed on the Program Faculty tab.
Program name: Minor in Native American and Indigenous Studies

Requirements: All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. The minor in Optics is administered by the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Completion of the minor requires 21 to 24 credits.

Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in philosophy. No more than six credits of transfer work may be used for the minor. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or higher. At least 12 credits must be in courses numbered 300 or higher. PHI 108 is a required course for the minor and may be used to satisfy three of the 18 credits.

Students should declare the minor as early as possible but no later than the last semester of their senior year by visiting the undergraduate program director in Physics and Astronomy. Completion of the minor in Physics requires a minimum of 20 credits. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. At least 12 credits of courses at the 300-level or higher must be taken at Stony Brook.

Declaration of the minor requires a minimum g.p.a. of 2.0. Completion of the minor requires a g.p.a. of 2.0 in all courses taken for the minor. All courses taken for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Program name: Minor in Real Estate and Insurance

Requirements:
The minor in religious studies requires 18 credits. No more than one course may be taken under the Pass/NC option.

1. RLS 101, What is Religion?
2. Five additional courses chosen from the list of approved courses below, including:
a. At least two RLS courses at the 300 level
b. No more than two courses from any one department other than Religious Studies.
Students interested in the minor should consult with the undergraduate director of the Department of Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures.

Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in courses approved for the minor. No more than nine credits may be from any one department. No more than six credits may be from courses taken at another institution. All courses for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher.

Students must declare the minor in Spanish no later than the first semester of their senior year. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 18 credits in Spanish beyond SPN 112.
Program name: Minor in Spanish Language and Literature

Requirements: Students wishing to minor in Sustainability Studies should meet with a SoMAS Undergraduate Adviser to declare the minor and plan a course of study. Students must have a g.p.a. of 2.0 or higher.

Interested students should email the undergraduate director, Julie Sheehan. The minor is open to all students, no matter what their major. Students must complete the minor with a GPA of 3.0 or higher in all courses taken for the minor. Prerequisites: Wrt 102 and CWL 202.

The minor in Theatre Arts provides students with a general introduction to the theory and practice of theatre. Students must take at least 21 credits for the Theatre Arts minor. All courses offered for the minor must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits.
Students should declare the minor in Women's and Gender Studies by the beginning of their junior year at the latest. To plan a course of study, they must meet with the Undergraduate Program Director.
Program name: Minor in Women's and Gender Studies

Requirements: To declare the minor, students must complete the Undergraduate Major/Minor Declaration form and submit it to the Program in Writing and Rhetoric office. All courses must be passed with a letter grade of C or higher. A minimum g.p.a. of 2.0 is required for the 18 credits.
